UserName.description: Username of the database user to create a certificate for.

CreatedAt.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 date and time format in UTC when Atlas created this X.509 certificate.

MonthsUntilExpiration.description: A number of months that the created certificate is valid for before expiry, up to 24 months.default 3.

NotAfter.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 date and time format in UTC when this certificate expires.

Subject.description: Fully distinguished name of the database user to which this certificate belongs. To learn more, see RFC 2253.

GroupId.description: Unique identifier of the Atlas project to which this certificate belongs.

Cas.description: PEM string containing one or more customer CAs for database user authentication.

description:
Generates one X.509 certificate for the specified MongoDB user. Atlas manages the certificate and MongoDB user that belong to one project. To use this resource, the requesting API Key must have the Project Atlas Admin role. This resource doesn't require the API Key to have an Access List.

To get MongoDB Cloud to generate a managed certificate for a database user, set `"x509Type" : "MANAGED"` on the desired MongoDB Database User.

If you are managing your own Certificate Authority (CA) in Self-Managed X.509 mode, you must generate certificates for database users using your own CA.

Links.description: One or more links to sub-resources and/or related resources.

TotalCount.description: Total number of unexpired certificates returned in this response.

CustomerX509.description: CustomerX509 represents Customer-managed X.509 configuration for an Atlas project.

UserName.description: Username of the database user to create a certificate for.

MonthsUntilExpiration.description: A number of months that the created certificate is valid for before expiry, up to 24 months.default 3.

ProjectId.description: The unique identifier for the project .

Results.description: List of one or more Uniform Resource Locators (URLs) that point to API sub-resources, related API resources, or both. RFC 5988 outlines these relationships.
